fields.summary: CSV Importer during issue-update is not attaching files if they have the same name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64638].
  {panel}

*Problem*:
Customer is migrating from Fogbugz On Demand to JIRA Cloud on a per project basis. The Fogbugz import for JIRA Server allows the mapping of fields that aren't available in the JIRA Cloud Fogbugz import tool.

Below you'll find the customers thorough walk through of the differences between the two import tool environments/mappings. 

{quote}
All screenshots have the Jira cloud importing Fogbugz OnDemand on the left and Jira server import Fogbugz SqlServer database on the right.

*Screen 1 - Projects*
This shows that both support individual project importing. However, you will see that server has one extra step as highlighted by the red underlines.

*Screen 2 - Custom Fields*
This shows the custom fields screen that server has. I do not care about this feature and have no need for it to be available for OnDemand import.

*Screen 3 - Fields*
This shows that the server adds three options for mapping imports that are not available with OnDemand. sFullName is the must have for us.

sCateogry and sPriority would be very nice to have, but I can deal with not having them.

*Screen 4 - Values*
This shows the ui for choosing what the mappings are. Once very nice thing with this is that the configuration file in the earlier steps remembers the mappings I created. So if I run through this for one of our projects we can use mostly the same configuration file for other projects. Also, since the configuration file is text I can write a script to do the user name mapping rather than having to fill in 400+ username ids :).

*Screen 5 - Links*
This shows that the server adds two more link import options. The critical one for us is the duplicate case mapping. See also is nice but we don't actually intentionally use that much.
{quote}
fields.summary: Fogbugz import tool for JIRA Cloud instance needs to mirror JIRA Server Fogbugz import tool
Make the Asana importer MPAC listing nicer

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64636].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is not possible to import issue security level using CSV import

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide feature to import security level for JIRA issue using CSV import

h3. Why this is important
Security is always a biggest concern for any system which this feature when we import issue via CSV import, the imported issues does not have the security level which was set earlier hence we will need to manually bulk edit issues to change the security level after the issue is imported.


h3. Workaround
Perform Bulk edit to change the security level of the issue that has been imported using CSV import
fields.summary: Ability To Import Security Level Using CSV Import

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64635].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When importing from an external system such as Bitbucket, basically the importer is able to map usernames to JIRA usernames correctly, and create new JIRA accounts when there is no username match in JIRA. However, sometimes usernames from the external system don't match usernames of the same users in JIRA, or on the other hand, usernames in the external system coincidentally match usernames of entirely different users in JIRA (disastrous), and there is no simple way to choose to map with other attributes.

This would probably apply to all External System Import. However, the context in the support case that led to this is Bitbucket to JIRA import. More details in the internal comment.

h3. Suggested Solution
Perform the by-username/by-whatever-it-is-the-importer-uses mapping, as it is being done now, but before the importer moves on to the next stage, allow the user to review and change the mappings manually (while validating consistency of user input, of course - no double mapping), then write the changes to the target directory.
fields.summary: Implement a more configurable mapping between users from External system to JIRA users when importing with JIM
Prevent the csv importer from unintentionally adding users, issue type etc

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64633].
  {panel}

When the importer fails to parse JSON, the error message says:

{noformat}
Import completed with 2 errors:
Failed to create data bean
Unexpected failure occurred. Importer will stop immediately. Data maybe in an unstable state
{noformat}

However:
# An end user doesn't know or care what a "data bean" is.
# The data is definitely not in an unstable state because we haven't done anything yet.
# The detailed log has an error message that gives the line number and column of the parsing error.

Suggested improvement:
* Report a more meaningful error and include the location directly in the report.  Example: The JSON import file could not be parsed.  Unexpected character ('T' (code 84)): expected a valid value (number, String, array, object, 'true', 'false' or 'null') at line: 2, column: 2
fields.summary: Error message for JSON parse errors is less helpful than it could be

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64632].
  {panel}

When importing is see a log of these messages:
WARN - Commenter named user@corporate.com not found. Creating issue with currently logged in user
WARN - User named user@corporate.com not found. attaching to issue with currently logged in user

Many old entries made by users which left long ago are incorrectly recorded as the admin users (me). The internal user DB is nearly empty and Jira is using AD. The "not found" users exist in AD, but are disabled.
LDAP user filter is NOT configured to hide disabled users.
"ldap.user.filter": "(&(objectCategory=Person)(sAMAccountName=*))"
When i search for the "not found" users in Jira User Management, i find them as inactive. So they are there.

I believe, this is a bug in the design!
Never should an enry be recorded under a wrong user, a user who was not the author/actor of it. That makes the whole imported project useless, if you cannot rely on its correctness. Please let the importing user decide how and if to record such an entry.
I would rather like to reassign open issues to active users after importing, than manually fixing the issues one by one (if possible at all).

Btw. i dont understand when importing partial historical data, why a user needs to exist. Can Jira not store entries from deleted users and still show their names?

Edit: This might be important:
The server runs with a 10 user license only, because we have less than 10 active users at the moment. The bugzilla importer filled the jira_users group up to its limit (10). I think, it should not add active or inactive users to roles/groups, unless told by the importing user.
fields.summary: Entries from disabled/deleted users are imported as currently loggined in user

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64631].
  {panel}

Currently Github Importer is importing users that:
- have reported at least one issue
- have written at least one comment
- are assigned to at least one issue

If user is only mentioned in comment or had none activity in imported project,  he will be omitted during import.
This behaviour is acceptable for importing projects from github.com. For Enterprise users it may be unintuitive.
fields.summary: Allow user to import all users from Github Enterprise
Following JSON import the Rank order of the issues is not numeric (as it would be if they were created manually)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64629].
  {panel}

When importing users into JIM from .csv files there is a use case for giving users the option to do something of the following:
* Import all those users, and put them into the jira-users group for example
* Import all those users, but have them as users who are not in any groups (not active and will not count towards the license count)
* Do not import users
fields.summary: JIRA Importers Plugin (JIM) to give the option to import users or not

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64628].
  {panel}

Hello,

I am using JIRA Cloud (fhassan.atlassian.net). I am trying to use the non-admin CSV importer to import issues into JIRA. The problem I am facing is that I am not able to import time logs. The 'Log Work' field doesn't show up at all in the map field screen.

Note that I added the 'Log Work' field to all screens but it didn't help.

Please advise.
fields.summary: Unable to map field to 'Log Work' JIRA field
Import time tracking data from Mantis

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64626].
  {panel}

Lets say customer just migrated all issues from Bugzilla successfully.
Each issue include a field called *External issue ID* which is a link of the issue to the original issue in Bugzilla.

Now he have perform migration the Bugzilla to a different server and need to change the URL.

He need a configuration to *update* the External Issue ID field in all of the existing JIRA issue which he had previously imported so that it will point to the latest URL to the new Bugzilla server.
fields.summary: allow modification on External Issue ID on JIRA which links to Bugzilla issue
Map categories as JIRA components/labels when importing issues from Redmine

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64624].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
As an admin I would like to associate CSV values with either the incoming or outgoing Issue linking descriptions
 
h3. Suggested Solution
Allow the user to pick the Inward description from the CSV importer. e.g.  !Screen Shot 2016-07-15 at 17.34.16.png|thumbnail!

So the list should show: 
blocks *and* is blocked by	
clones *and* is cloned by
duplicates  *and* is duplicated by
causes *and* is caused by
relates to *and* relates to

Not just the outward descriptions (blocks etc)
fields.summary: CSV importer should allow association with both inward and outward links

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64623].
  {panel}

Currently when importing from Mantis, there're 3 options for project mapping:
# Map to an existing project
# Create a new project manually and map to this project
# Don't map to any project

It would be great if there's another option e.g. Create As-Is which means a new project will be automatically created in JIRA using the name of the Mantis project.

This might be complicated though as JIRA will need to check for available project keys to be used.
fields.summary: Allow Mantis importer to automatically create JIRA projects
Asana will soon stop supporting the API Key

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64621].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
There is a use-case in which the {{case #ID}} from other external system is included in the summary of Bugzilla. Importing those bugs with the summary will map the case #ID to a new JIRA Issue key based on the Bugzilla ID which is incorrect for this case.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide an option during the Bugzilla import to disable the {{case #ID}} mapping on all fields but the Bugzilla ID for the import
 
h3. Workaround 
Not known.
fields.summary: Option to disable automatic mapping of case #ID

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64620].
  {panel}

If you try to import CSV, after you press import CSV will create records or throw errors for each parsing error.

Currently there is no option to preview / validate the data, meaning that you cannot really run import on production because it will mess the database almost for sure and even when you run it on a test instance you do have to do a LOT of bulk removal in order to remove the partial imports.

So far do I not see any reliable way to import many issues from CSV.

The desired behavior would be one that would show you the errors, allowing you to re-upload the files and "preview" the import again, so you will perform the operation only when all the data is sanitized.
fields.summary: Ability to preview / cancel a CSV Import
Add factory method to ExternalCustomFieldValue
EditTest

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64617].
  {panel}

It's spawned from JIM-228

I see three solutions:
a) have file upload on a separate screen
b) use gmail-like file upload (asynchronous), so that when the validation fails there is no need for re-uploading
c) (minimal solution) provide a clear warning message about the need to re-browse and re-upload your cfg file when the validation files.
fields.summary: Streamline file upload (and related validation/error handling) to avoid confusion or the need of re-upload
Issues that were imported partially should be removed
Due date not imported from redmine
Allow to use periods for worklog entries when importing CSV
Improve Mantis Importer
Auto truncate text longer than 255 characters when importing it into a Text Field (< 255 characters)
No way to add Value Mapping for users defined in Comments column
Ability to import Pivotal Tracker to a Scrum Rapid Baord
When importing change history from Sample Data fill missing values from well known stringValues
Allow dateOffSet to be factored in when importing from JSON
Include validation button on Admin CSV importer
Warn users that "udapted" is not respected when issue has some logged work

fields.summary: I want JIM to understand ansi_x3.110-1983 and unicode-1-1-utf-7 encodings
CSV Importer Time Estimate should be able to configure other time formats than just seconds
JIRA Importers plugin should have parameters for importing data

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64602].
  {panel}

New users which are created by JIM in OD environment are only granted with JIRA access, access to other applications has to be enabled manually after import.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Prepare OD instance with different license limit for each application (e.g. JIRA 50, Confluence 50, Bamboo unlimited)
2. Import new users by any JIM importer (e.g. 60 users via JSON)

Expected behaviour:
Imported users are granted access to all active applications.
Licnese limit for each application is respected.
Import log indicates which users was granted with application access.

Actual behaviour:
Imported users are only granted access to JIRA application
License limit for JIRA is respected.
fields.summary: New users created by JIM on OD has only JIRA access.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64601].
  {panel}

At the moment, CSV import does not has the ability to auto-format the escape characters specified in the Comments or Description fields. When we use escape characters in the Comment or Description fields, it appears as with the escape characters after the import.

It should support the escape characters like:
- \r (Return)
- \n (Newline)
- \t (Tab)
fields.summary: CSV Importer should has the ability to auto-format the escape characters
Errors parsing dates should count as failures

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64599].
{panel}
h3. +Summary+

There're 2 ways to import issues into JIRA using CSV:
 # [Bulk Create|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracoreserver073/creating-issues-using-the-csv-importer-861257331.html]
 # [CSV External System Import|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver073/importing-data-from-csv-861253680.html]

The basic differences between these 2 are:
|| ||Bulk Create||CSV External System Import||
|JIRA Action|Is a Create action performed by any user - similar to clicking the Create button and creating an issue normally|Is an Import action performed by JIRA Admins only|
|Admin Permissions|JIRA Admin permissions not required|JIRA Admin permissions required|
|Issue Statuses|Issues are created newly and take the initial status in the workflow they're created with|Issues can be imported into any available status in the workflow they're associated with|
|Issue Event|Issue Created event is guaranteed to be fired|No event is fired as it's impossible to predict which events are going to be involved|

(+) Due to this:
 * If Bulk Create is used, Issue Created event is fired which triggers WebHooks that listen on this event
 * If CSV External System Import is used, Issue Created event, or, if updating existing issue, Issue Updated event,  are NOT fired thus WebHooks / plugin / Automation for Jira/ etc  listening on this event won't be triggered

h3. +Suggestion+

Add the ability to fire events when issues are imported using CSV External System Import.
h3. +Workaround+

For Issue Created event, use Bulk Create instead.

(!) Bulk Create has more limited features than CSV External System Import.

 
{panel:title=Original Description}
Issue Created Event is not triggered when issue are created using CSV import.

This makes it impossible to trigger notifications or webhooks for issues created from CSV.

I am createing an plugins which send and notification to our tool whenever an Issue is created. We are unable to trapped the Issue Created Event at the time of CSV import.

Even We are unable to distict the issue which are created using CSV import.
{panel}
fields.summary: Issue Created or Issue Updated events are not trapped when importing issues using CSV External System Import
Add support for longcf plugin that adds additional custom fields to Mantis
When mapping values from CSV files to a select custom field show options that are defined
JIM Should not use ViewStatuses WW action code
Support importing into a custom field with multiple contexts / configuration schemes
Support QA Contact and Alias and any other built-in custom fields in Bugzilla
Do not warn about missing links
External Issue ID should be always re-used if it exists
Allow JSON Importer to update projects
Support mapping custom fields into matching (by type) standard fields (like Computer -> Environment)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64589].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
* In the Map Fields screen of the CSV import wizard, the fields are being shown as localized field names. This can cause confusion because the localized names are ambiguous, i.e. the localization can apply to more than one field.

h3. Suggested Solution
* To have an option for user to be able to show the fields, "Display Field Names in Localized Fashion" or "Display Raw Field Names" or something to that effect.
fields.summary: Fields in Map Fields Screen of CSV Import Wizard is showing localized field name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64588].
  {panel}

Hi,

it's great for us to use the CSV-Importer for uploading issues including comments with datetime and user information.
After uploading all issues the Activity Stream shows an exact history. When uploading attachments the automatically generated
attachment destroys this history view. (see screenshot).

Kind Regards
Udo Ottink
fields.summary: Option for importing attachments, to disable automatically generated comments

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64587].
  {panel}

We use the CSV importer to regularly import new issues from the bug tracking system of a customer.
With the wizard it was very easy to initially define a mapping between the 2 systems.

The problem is, the CSV importer of Jira can do only INSERT, no UPDATE.
So we have to manually update Jira to keep it in sync with the customers bug tracker.
Our customers do not change very often the issues after we get them, but sometimes they do
and as projects are getting bigger this is becoming too much to handle manually.

Are there any plans to add to the CSV importer the capability to update already imported issues?

Or are there any other solutions to this problem?
Are there any "standard" Jira solutions?

As I see the Jira CSV importer was created as a tool to import data from another system once,
not to keep data in sync between two systems. But with a small extension it could be made into one.
I just could not find this issue anywhere here in Jira's Jira. We need a solution quite urgently.

Regards
Bettina Zucker
fields.summary: Extend JIM to UPDATE already imported issues
Detect if disk attachments are enabled and require site credentials only if they are
Allow user to choose Default Assignee for component during import

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64584].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

When importing comments using the JSON importer it's not currently possible to specify comment visibility.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow the importing of comment visibility.
 
h3. Workaround

Import the comments and then alter after importing.
fields.summary: Import comment visibility
JIM - allow to import by users other than global admins
Ability to map all fields during the import
Allow putting a symlink in JIRA_HOME/import/attachments to external directory
JIM doesn't allow mapping to fields that are limited to certain issue types
Import Pivotal sprints into GH sprints (not versions)
Not providing a required field to the CSV importer prevents import - more detailed error required

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64577].
  {panel}

*Problem Defination*

Redmine Importer Plugin for JIM seems have yet to be updated for JIRA 7 and still at version 2.1.5

*Suggested Solution*

Provide the needed update to JIRA 7 users so that they will be able to import the issues from redmine 3.2.0
fields.summary: Redmine Importers Plugin JIM update JIRA 7.x
Bugzilla importer should allow users to map all issues to any issue types

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64575].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

Currently the CSV import does not allow for importing issue history.

h3. Suggested Solution

Provide functionality to allow importing of issue history.
 
h3. Workaround 

As detailed in [Importing data from JSON|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer071/Importing+data+from+JSON], it is possible to import history using the JSON import.
fields.summary: As someone importing I want to be able to include issue history in CSV format
As a JIRA admin I would like JIM to support a Mingle importer
Do not import unused users if external user management is turned on

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64572].
  {panel}

Customer scenario: We had a user that wanted to use the csv importer to create new stories with "is a story in" link to an existing Feature (see attached "NewStoryImport.csv"). However, when using the csv importer, it only creates the link "stories" when creating a NEW Story to an EXISTING Feature – it creates the link backwards to what the user wants.


Steps to import:
# JIRA Admin -> System -> External System Import -> Import from Comm-separated values(CSV)
# Choose a file to import then to project
# At Map Field page when you link this new issue to existing issue, it only show Outward description list.
#* It will be great to list the Inward Description list or Allow to map link endpoints.
# Once imported it creates the link backwards.
fields.summary: Allow to list Inward Description list during mapping

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64571].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

When importing issues through CSV, the JIM will try to update, rather than create new issues under some circumstances (a match on an Issue Key, or External ID value). This might not always be desirable.


h3. Suggested Solution

Provide an option to 'do not update existing issues' and instead create new issues for these entries within the CSV file.


h3. Workaround

When importing issues from CSV from an external service where a parent -> Child relationship exists between different entities a user must map the Issue Id and Parent Id's. 

These values are used and persisted within the External ID custom field.

Under some circumstances, it may not be desirable to persist this External ID longer term. Having this External ID allows for updating issues. 

You can consider removing this External ID from issues that you would not like to update through the JIRA CSV Import functionality provided by JIM.
fields.summary: Provide option to prevent updating existing issues when importing from External Systems
document that you can import CSV labels in 1 column
Make JSON Export complete and stable so it can be enabled by default
When mapping CSV fields it would be useful to have summary etc. at the top of the select list

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64567].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
JIM will only reuse a Custom Field if it has a matching type as specified in table below. Any other cross-type imports will take no effect and will force JIM to create a new field.

|| Bugzilla Field || Expected Custom Field Type in JIRA ||
| bug_url | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:url |
| bug_severity | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:select |
| priority | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:select |
| status_whiteboard | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:text |
| Bugzilla Custom Field of type '2' | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:select |
| Bugzilla Custom Field of type '3' | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:multiselect |
| Bugzilla Custom Field of type '4' | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:textarea |
| Bugzilla Custom Field of type '5' | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:datetime |
| Bugzilla Custom Field of type '6' | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:textfield |
| Every other Bugzilla Custom Field Type | com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:textfield |

h3. Suggested Solution
Improve Bugzilla text field import and allow to map this field to user-picket for example.
fields.summary: Improve Bugzilla text field import

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64566].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
The JIRA Importer enforces a connection to a MySQL Database that uses the InnoDB Engine. This can not be configured from the "Advanced" JDBC Settings.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Error occurs When attempting to connect to Mantis when using the JIRA Importer tool:
# Log into JIRA and goto the *External System Import* page.
# Select: *Import from Mantis*
# Attempt to connect to a MyISAM database
# Observe in the {{atlassian-jira.log}} the following exception:
{code}
com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLNonTransientConnectionException: Could not create connection to database server. Attempted reconnect 3 times. Giving up.

	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(Unknown Source)

	at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Unknown Source)

	at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.getInstance(ConnectionImpl.java:399)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.NonRegisteringDriver.connect(NonRegisteringDriver.java:325)

	at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.importer.web.JdbcConnection.validateConnection(JdbcConnection.java:235)

	at com.atlassian.prettyurls.filter.PrettyUrlsCombinedMatchDispatcherFilter.doFilter(PrettyUrlsCombinedMatchDispatcherFilter.java:61)  <+13> (DelegatingPluginFilter.java:78) (IteratingFilterChain.java:42) (ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:77) (ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:63) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (ProfilingFilter.java:99) (JIRAProfilingFilter.java:19) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (AbstractJohnsonFilter.java:71) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208)
	at org.tuckey.web.filters.urlrewrite.RuleChain.handleRewrite(RuleChain.java:176)
	at org.tuckey.web.filters.urlrewrite.RuleChain.doRules(RuleChain.java:145)
	at org.tuckey.web.filters.urlrewrite.UrlRewriter.processRequest(UrlRewriter.java:92)  <+10> (UrlRewriteFilter.java:394) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (GzipFilter.java:82) (GzipFilter.java:59) (JiraGzipFilter.java:55) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (IteratingFilterChain.java:46) (DelegatingPluginFilter.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.analytics.client.filter.JiraAnalyticsFilter.doFilter(JiraAnalyticsFilter.java:40)
	at com.atlassian.analytics.client.filter.AbstractHttpFilter.doFilter(AbstractHttpFilter.java:32)  <+3> (DelegatingPluginFilter.java:78) (IteratingFilterChain.java:42) (DelegatingPluginFilter.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.prettyurls.filter.PrettyUrlsCombinedMatchDispatcherFilter.doFilter(PrettyUrlsCombinedMatchDispatcherFilter.java:61)  <+40> (DelegatingPluginFilter.java:78) (IteratingFilterChain.java:42) (ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:77) (ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:63) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (ChainedFilterStepRunner.java:87) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (AbstractCachingFilter.java:33) (AbstractHttpFilter.java:31) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (AbstractEncodingFilter.java:41) (AbstractHttpFilter.java:31) (PathMatchingEncodingFilter.java:49) (AbstractHttpFilter.java:31) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (JiraStartupChecklistFilter.java:79) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (MultipartBoundaryCheckFilter.java:41) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (ChainedFilterStepRunner.java:87) (JiraFirstFilter.java:60) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:241) (ApplicationFilterChain.java:208) (StandardWrapperValve.java:220) (StandardContextValve.java:122) (AuthenticatorBase.java:501) (StandardHostValve.java:171) (ErrorReportValve.java:103) (StandardEngineValve.java:116) (AccessLogValve.java:950) (CoyoteAdapter.java:408) (AbstractHttp11Processor.java:1070) (AbstractProtocol.java:611) (JIoEndpoint.java:314)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.tomcat.util.threads.TaskThread$WrappingRunnable.run(TaskThread.java:61)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)
Caused by: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLSyntaxErrorException: Unknown storage engine 'InnoDB'
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Unknown Source)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.Util.handleNewInstance(Util.java:389)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.SQLError.createSQLException(SQLError.java:980)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.checkErrorPacket(MysqlIO.java:3835)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.checkErrorPacket(MysqlIO.java:3771)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.sendCommand(MysqlIO.java:2435)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.sqlQueryDirect(MysqlIO.java:2582)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.execSQL(ConnectionImpl.java:2531)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.StatementImpl.executeUpdate(StatementImpl.java:1618)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.StatementImpl.executeUpdate(StatementImpl.java:1549)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.setSessionVariables(ConnectionImpl.java:5070)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.initializePropsFromServer(ConnectionImpl.java:3246)
	at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.connectWithRetries(ConnectionImpl.java:2112)
	... 204 more
	{code}

h3. Expected Results
There should be a way to set the Engine type to MyISAM when importing issues. While it is important for JIRA to enforce the InnoDB Engine, this should not be the case when importing information from an External System.


h3. Actual Results

When connecting to the Mantis Server the {{atlassian-jira.log}} shows the connection string being used:
{code}
2015-01-01 01:01:01,001 http-bio-8080-exec-1 INFO admin 100x8908x1 idjmdi 192.168.0.2 /secure/admin/ImporterSetupPage.jspa [plugins.importer.web.JdbcConnection] Connecting to JDBC using connection string: jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/mantistest?useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=UTF8&sessionVariables=storage_engine=InnoDB&autoReconnect=true&useUnicode=true&zeroDateTimeBehavior=convertToNull&useCursorFetch=true&defaultFetchSize=100
{code}


h3. Workaround

The Importer will not able to work until the InnoDB engine is enabled the MySQL server. Therefore, enable the InnoDB Engine as per database vendor instructions.
fields.summary: Mantis importer unnecessarily requires InnoDB on source MySQL server

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64565].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Customers are trying to migrate from Codebase to JIRA.  At this time, there is not a native option to directly import from this other system and the CSV/JSON Import process requires significant modification to the data in order to make it compatible for importing. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement a native import option from Codebase

h3. Workaround 
CSV/JSON Import

h5. Possible workaround:
If Codebase was used as a Code Repository, it may be possible to import the data into [BitBucket|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Import+or+convert+code+from+an+existing+tool] and then use JIM to do an Import from [BitBucket to JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer071/Importing+data+from+Bitbucket].
fields.summary: Native JIRA Import from Codebase

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64564].
  {panel}

We could allow users to choose if they would like to have JIRA Issue Keys with the same numer as their external Issue ID/Key.

Now:
Issues are importer one after the other always starting from KEY-1
Real External Issue ID is saved in Custom Field "External ID"

Users are usually importing their external system (e.g. Bugzilla) to the new JIRA project, so we could try to force create JIRA issues with specified number in Issue Key.
fields.summary: Allow users to preserve Issue Id/Issue Keys from external systems

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64563].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Add Check or Warning for Created Dates set in the future


h3. Steps to Reproduce
Import a csv that has dates set in the future for created dates

h3. Expected Results
A warning should pop up to alert you to the fact that the dates are set in the future, and offer a click to proceed if desired.

h3. Actual Results
Issues will be created with dates set in the future.
fields.summary: Add Check or Warning for Created Dates set in the future
FogBugz Importer does not convert Subscribers to Watchers
Filter users that do not belong to a group or are imported to JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64560].
  {panel}

Currently we import all users from Asana, which might be a bit of overhead.

As [~pborkowski] mentioned in PR:
{quote}
I guess this returns all workspaces in the destination Asna instance? We can be smart here - this method is used during import itself, but from the first step of wizard we know what project/workspaces were chosen for import - we can then extract users just from workspaces selected for import.

This should be somehow available from ConfigBean
{quote}

 

It looks a bit tricky from the code perspective.

With given APIs we should:
 # Get selected product names (mind there are 'special' project names).
 # Fetch all the project, for the given names.
 # Get workspace id's for the given names.
 # Fetch only users for the given worskpace ids.
fields.summary: Asana - import only project-related users
Create Issue History in JIRA when Importing Issues from Mantis
Native JIRA Import from Gemini
"Bug Import ID" is redundant compared to "Import Id"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64556].
  {panel}

Tested in CSV, but may be happening elsewhere.

We should inform the user that the configuration is wrong, in the same way we do for multiple columns with same header:
- if the field can receive multiple values, say nothing (and do as expected)
- if the field cannot receive multiple values, like Summary, display a warning and add fail messages if proceed (fail because we get data loss - user thinks he imported data from column X but it was discarded)
fields.summary: When I map multiple values to the same field only the first value is used and the other are SILENTLY ignored
When you type some project name in Add Project combo and this project does not exist you should be able to easily create it.
Ability to auto-mapping JIRA project with Bugzilla Project during second steps of importing process.
Include Category field to CSV importer
Native JIRA Import from Microsoft TFS
Map Mantis Categories as Issue Types
Allow mapping Mantis's Custom Field to existing JIRA's Custom Field
Add ability to choose which custom field to be imported
Add ability to filter imported issues based on simple criteria and perform partial project imports

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64547].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
The current Atlassian REST API Browser version is not compatible for JIRA 7.1.7. Customer have some users that require this plugin and used it very often.

h3. Suggestion
Release a compatible version for JIRA 7.1.7
fields.summary: Implement a compatible version of Atlassian REST API Browser plugin for JIRA 7.1.7
Issues might be imported with an arbitrary status

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64545].
  {panel}

Currently the only missing piece for a proper import of Agile data (from JIRA Agile or other systems) is the inability to import Sprints.

While JSON importer can import Sprint assignments, it cannot import the Sprints themselves. 

Current REST API of JIRA Agile does not allow user to edit the Sprint status (as in started / in progress / ended)

A Sprint has these code properties that should be imported by JSON:
* Name (mandatory)
* Start Date (optional)
* End Date (optional)
* Status (mandatory, any of planned, running, ended)

I know that implementing this may require collaboration with GHS team, but don't ignore the importance of it, it does prevent others from migrating form their systems to JIRA+AGILE.
fields.summary: Allow proper import of Agile Sprints
Importer should try to guess mapped columns

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64543].
  {panel}

According to the CSV [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Importing+Data+from+CSV#ImportingDatafromCSV-EncapsulatingJIRAdatastructureinyourCSVfile], you are able to update an existing issue by mapping the issue key on the CSV file to the JIRA field *Issue Key*.

However, if you want to update a subtask, you must map the issue key on the CSV file to the JIRA field *Issue ID*.  If you try to update a subtask, JIRA will throw the exception "n of n issues have been skipped because they already exist in destination projects."

!exist.png!

It would great to be able to update a subtask through CSV import.
fields.summary: As a user, I would like to update an existing subtask through CSV import

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-64542].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

Issues in Pivotal in the "Accepted" status should have their resolution set when being imported to JIRA.
h3. Suggested Solution

Set the *Resolution* to Done for issues in the 'Accepted' state.
h3. Workaround

Define a transition and bulk-edit Issues after the fact. For example, using steps similar to those in [How to Edit the Resolution of an Issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/How+to+Edit+the+Resolution+of+an+Issue]
fields.summary: Set Resolution for "Accepted" Status during import from Pivotal Tracker
It should be possible to disable/post pone re-indexing
Allow non-admins to update issues via CSV
